fields.description:
If you enable GZIP compression, and try to connect a Crowd Client to the Crowd Server, the responses are uncompressed, and the content-encoding is unset.

{code}
Content-Encoding: 
Vary: 
{code}

Also, by leaving it unset, there is a conflict with mod_deflate + Apache when using mod_proxy where it'll output its headers as "Content-Encoding: , gzip" where the comma confuses the client (although you shouldn't really need mod_deflate if you've enabled gzip in Crowd).

Some searching shows that the problem is in atlassian-gzip, and it also affected JIRA: [JRA-15658|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-15658].

I tested upgrading my atlassian-gzipfilter library to 1.9 and that appeared to fix the problem where the contents were actually compressed, and the headers were properly written.
fields.summary: Content-Encoding is unset for SOAP requests

fields.description:
A routine license upgrade will cause the server to go into an unresponsive state requiring a restart; however no warning is given about this during the upgrade process.

Ideally this shouldn't require a restart but if it does then the final step of upgrading the license should warn that this operation will cause the server to become unresponsive until a restart is issued.   An option for the server to restart itself would be useful too.
fields.summary: License upgrade causes server to go catatonic without warning

fields.description:
The internal directory should be case-insensitive so that it's implementation is similar to LDAP directories, which are case insensitive when finding a user, group or role by name.

It is worth noting that currently the InternalDirectory:
- only allows users with lower-case usernames
- allows groups and roles with mixed case names
fields.summary: Make the InternalDirectory case-insensitive

fields.description:
The client caches are case-sensitive. LDAP directories are case-insensitive with respect to user/group/role names. Internal directories are case-sensitive but only allow lower case usernames.

Going forward it makes more sense to have case-insensitive client cache to ensure compatibility with LDAP schemas and consistent with the internal directory. This allows a user to "Bill" in an LDAP directory to be found even if a user enters "bill".
fields.summary: Make the client caches case-insensitive

fields.description: Currently the directory caches are case-sensitive. As almost all LDAP directory schemas are case-insensitive for user/group/role names, in order to mimic the LDAP directory calls properly, the cache should also be case-insensitive.
fields.summary: Make the DirectoryCache case-insensitive

fields.description:
Currently, Crowd sends email notifications when a user is within 10% of the maximum number of users allowed under a particular license.

This can be rather annoying if the number of users is static. Instead, Crowd should send emails as the number of users grows - mails should be sent at (say) every percent change within 10%.

It will be nice if we could adjust the threshold and frequency the email will be sent out as well, as we do not need the email to remind us daily
fields.summary: Improve email notifications about license limits

fields.description: Some users may not have enabled SSO before releasing into a production environment.  This can cause a panic if they suddenly discover accessing the Crowd Console via http://localhost no longer works.  When they attempt to login, and the page simply redirects again to the login page again without any errors and warnings on the login page.  Another usage scenario is that they misconfigure the SSO Domain value and suddenly can't log back in to fix it.
fields.summary: Provide user feedback if SSO Domain setting is preventing users from logging in

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 8 June 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hello everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Crowd team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-server-bug-fix-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication.

Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Crowd Team
{panel}
 
Having Crowd integrated with Confluence and the following Directories assigned to the application:
-> Internal: Containing confluence-users group
-> AD-Connector: Containing a *confluence-users* group and its nested group, *nested_to_confluence-users*

Group *nested_to_confluence-users* contains user *nested_user*

This user will be able to login into Confluence only if directory AD-Connector is the fist on the Applications Directories list.

If the Internal directory is the first of the list, the user can try to login into Confluence but will receive a *Not Permitted* message.

(See attached screenshot)
fields.summary: Crowd-AD with nested groups doesn't allow a user to login into Confluence if the AD Directory is not the first of the list

fields.description:
Matthew's description:
{quote}
We have "User Object Class" set to inetorgperson.  For most users this is their structural class and everything works however some users have a different structural class which is a child of inetorgperson.  These users cannot login because isOfObjectClass() only checks the objectclass attributes not all their parents so the users ldap entry is not recognised by isPrincipal().

OpenLDAP wont let me add inetorgperson as another objectclass for these entries and we cannot change our ldap schema because other systems use it.  So right now some of our users can't use Crowd authenticated systems.
{quote}

{{EntityContextMapper}} is the replacement for {{GenericFetcher}}. It reads all the {{objectclass}} attributes on a user to check if one contains the correct {{objectclass}}, which in this case is {{inetOrgPerson}}. If inetOrgPerson is not an objectclass on the user, Crowd will not go to the schema and check if the objectclass that's present inherits from it.

Doing this would involve a huge performance hit to handle a fairly unusual edge case. To be honest, it's unlikely we'll ever implement this functionality.
fields.summary: EntityContextMapper.isOfObjectClass() doesn't check objectclasses for inheritance in the schema definition

fields.description:

*The problem:* In IE7, the additional checkboxes do not appear immediately. You have to tab out of the "Enable Caching" field first.

fields.description:
Since we only support latin1 encoding at the moment for MySQL, we should specify in the connection JDBC URL *characterEncoding=latin1* and *useUnicode=true*.  This is important if the users have installed their MySQL to use UTF8 as their default encoding.  If this isn't implemented, it can lead to [illegal collation errors|http://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=179077288].  

This should be revisited after implementing utf8 support in Crowd for MySQL.

useUnicode=true sounds a bit counter-intuitive but according to [MySQL's docs|http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.0/en/connector-j-reference-configuration-properties.html], the characterEncoding parameter is only evaluated if useUnicode is true.
fields.summary: Setup Wizard for MySQL connection doesn't specify characterEncoding

Note: We'll need to update the *documentation*, whichever way the decision goes.

fields.description:
Initially, having the following error:
{noformat}
2008-11-12 18:24:31,103 TP-Processor34 WARN [org.openid4java.server.RealmVerifier] RP discovery / realm validation disabled; this option SHOULD be enabled for OPs
{noformat}
In order to fix it, the following modification to the serverManager Spring configuration ({{atlassian-crowd-1.5.2/crowd-openidserver-webapp/WEB-INF/classes/applicationContext-OpenIDServer.xml}}) should create a RealmVerifier with RP Discovery enabled. 
{code:xml}
    <bean id="serverManager" class="org.openid4java.server.ServerManager">
        <property name="privateAssociations" ref="associationStore"/>
        <property name="sharedAssociations" ref="associationStore"/>
        <!-- edit this to reflect the URL of the OpenID server: -->
        <property name="OPEndpointUrl" value="http://localhost:8087/openidserver/server"/>
        <property name="userSetupUrl" value="http://localhost:8087/openidserver/server"/>
        <property name="realmVerifier">
            <bean class="org.openid4java.server.RealmVerifier"/>

{code}

fields.description:
It may be a good idea for the "Add Application" wizard to prompt users to configure the application after completing the wizard. Now that we have a wizard, it's tempting to think you've done everything once you have completed the wizard.

Suggestion: Add a hint, containing something like the following text:
{quote}
After completing the 'Add Application' wizard, please configure your application as described in the [online documentation|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Adding+an+Application].
{quote}

*Note* that the link in the above text should be version-specific, as are the online help links.

We could add the hint at the bottom of the "Confirmation" tab in the wizard. (See screenshot 1.)
Or we could add it as a green message at the top of the first screen which appears after the wizard is finished i.e. the "View Application --- Details" screen. (See screenshot 2.)
fields.summary: Add Application Wizard should prompt users to configure the application after completing the wizard

fields.description:
In the "Add Application" wizard, you can add groups to the "Authorisation" tab. If you have not yet completed the wizard, you can also remove the groups that you recently added.

At the moment, the UI is not clear. It offers the already-added groups as a hyperlink. The user is tempted to click the link to see the group details. There _is_ a tooltip telling you that the link will remove the group, but this is not clear, particularly if you do not hover over the link, or if you click the link quickly. See the "cowd-administrators" link in the attached screenshot.

Instead, how about offering a red "X" to remove a group?
fields.summary: Improve UI for removing groups in the Add Application Wizard

fields.description:
See https://extranet.atlassian.com/jira/browse/ADM-2735

{code}
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance">
	<soap:Body>
		<ns1:searchPrincipals xmlns:ns1="urn:SecurityServer">
			<ns1:in0>
				<name xmlns="http://authentication.integration.crowd.atlassian.com">xxx</name>
				<token xmlns="http://authentication.integration.crowd.atlassian.crowd">xxx</token>
			</ns1:in0>
			<ns1:in1/>
		</ns1:searchPrincipals>
	</soap:Body>
</soap:Envelope>
{code} 

Causes crowd to return all principals, which consumes an potentially unlimited amount of heap, cpu and db resources.
fields.summary: Crowd does not protect itself against searchPrincipals without a predicate

fields.description:
XFire issues an Expect header on the SOAP request, this causes apache to reply with a HTTP/1.1 100 Continue before it can send the request body. This adds two extra packets on the wire for no added value. 

{code}
POST /crowd/services/SecurityServer HTTP/1.1
SOAPAction: ""
Content-Type: text/xml; charset=UTF-8
Accept-Encoding: gzip
User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 6.0; Windows NT 5.0; XFire Client +http://xfire.codehaus.org)
Host: atlassian10.private:8080
Expect: 100-continue
Content-Length: 503

HTTP/1.1 100 Continue

<soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> ...
{code}
fields.summary: Crowd (xfire) issues Expect: 100-continue, this adds two round trips

fields.description:
SSO with Crowd and Confleunce worked like a charm out of the box.

JIRA refused to start with the libs copied and the changes appplied to osuser.xml and seraph-config.xml
Replacing xfire-core and xfire-aegis like [CSP-19207|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/KB/CSP-19207+-+Confluence+Crowd+integration+not+working+after+adding+http+proxy] didn't help.

At last, deleting them both and coping xfire-all from the confluence libs folder solved the problem.

Sorry, that I don't have access to the error logs.
fields.summary: proxy issues with xfire and jira

fields.description:
When I call the Crowd Integration Client (Java) webservice with 1000 users it takes 1500+ seconds to create the users. This is very slow if you have 5000 users that need to be created in a batch. I am aware of the batch console feature but the webservice is needed because many time a batch of users are created on the fly in our apps.


Solution:


Add batch support to the webservice implementation that exposes the current the csv batch importer

Forum thread on this:

http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257289266&#257289266
fields.summary: Add batch support for the Crowd Integration Client (Java) webservice to improve batch speed

fields.description:
Currently, a client application can "see" all the principals in the directories configured for that application.

Ideally, if Allow All To Authenticate on a directory is set to False, only the principals that belong to the configured groups should be visible to the application. If Allow All To Authenticate on a directory is set to True, then the current behaviour of retrieving all groups is acceptable.

In addition to the SSC findAllPrincipalNames() method, there should be some sort of findAllAuthenticatablePrincipalNames()
fields.summary: Client applications should only see principals which have been authorised to access the application

fields.description:
Improve the speed of directory access by using event-driven caches on the server side. 

These remote directories can be monitored by opening LDAP persistent searches or polling the directory for mutations (depending on the remote directory implementation).
fields.summary: Implement server-side remote directory caching
Properly find the Deleted Objects container if the baseDN is not the root of the AD domain
Implement "flush cache" button for event caches.
Implement role disable checkbox for caching directories to avoid object duplication

fields.description: compatibility
fields.summary: Spring-ldap 1.3-RC1 changed the way authentication happens with Open Directory - maintain compatibility

fields.description:
Now that we're approaching the release of 1.6, the help links in 1.5 should be redirected to the CROWD015 space.

Please update the .htaccess file to redirect the help calls from Crowd 1.5 to the CROWD015 space, and to send help calls from Crowd 1.6 to the CROWD space.

(i) It's probably a good idea to schedule this one for the day before the release of 1.6
fields.summary: Configure redirection of context-sensitive online help links for existing 1.5 release

fields.description: It would be really nice, if it is possible to define groups as standard groups (e.g. jira-users) so that when a new user is created than gets automatically these groups.
fields.summary: Automatic adding of standard groups to a new created user

fields.description: AD over SSL is noticeably slower in Crowd than non-SSL connections.  We should run tests with profiling to further investigate the cause and possible options for further optimization.  Perhaps this is a problem with Spring LDAP and SSL?
fields.summary: Investigate AD over SSL performance in Crowd

fields.description:
OS X 10.5.6 Build 9G21 has changed the username required when authenticating. You now logon with full DN rather than username. This is consistent with other OpenLDAP-based directories, but requires a change to the Crowd Open Directory connector.

Solution is to provide (another :-( ) checkbox that allows the user to specify if username or full DN should be used when logging onto Open Directory.
fields.summary: Provide support for OS X Open Directory 10.5.6

fields.description: Plugins 2.1.2 is out, with fixed module dependency loading. We need to update.
fields.summary: Update Crowd to Plugins 2.1.2

fields.description:
It makes a lot of sense for Crowd to deal with certificates and act as a certificate authority. This especially makes sense for client certificates!

Take as an example a product called EJBCA.
fields.summary: Allow Crowd to act as a certificate authority

fields.description:
When importing Users, Groups and Memberships from AD via the Directory Importer.

The current implementation only returns direct relationships for Users using the memberOf attribute (if importing from AD).

We may need to look at reversing the import to import from groups and their members, so we can return a flattened view of the groups for import.
fields.summary: Support Nested Groups when importing User, Groups and Memberships into a Delegated Directory.

fields.description:
When offering a list of directory connectors for selection, we now present the connectors in alphabetical order. This means that, when adding a directory connector, the default selection is the first one in the list (currently Apache Directory Server).

Instead, it would be nice to default to Microsoft Active Directory as the selected connector, and yet still offer the dropdown in alphabetical order.
fields.summary: Directory connector dropdown should default to Microsoft Active Directory

fields.description:
Can someone please create a tomcat realm for authentication to crowd. It would make sense for this to work with tomcat 6. The current way of creating SSO between crowd and custom applications is not satisfactory for clients who purchase crowd and already have custom applications. I would have to alter at least 30 projects to achieve SSO with crowd. Not to mention the countless jars that are needed to achieve that solution. I would be very suprised if there were not some kind of dependency issues. 

I am open to other suggestions but the realm seems the most logical way of offering a solution to parties with existing applications.
fields.summary: Authentication Realm for Tomcat

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 19 April 2019|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hello everyone,

We’re happy to say that we have delivered Early Access Program for License Usage monitoring in Crowd.

You can find more details here: https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/license-usage-center-by-crowd-data-center-at-atlassian-summit-2019-las-vegas-968680984.html

Best regards,

Marek Radochonski
Senior Product Manager, Crowd
 [mradochonski@atlassian.com|mailto:mradochonski@atlassian.com]
 
{panel}

Please track the last logon for each user.  This is crucial for managing the user base and removing inactive users.  Please generate reports of least active or inactive users.  This helps admins keep their user base clean.  With hard limits to number of users, and many admins creating users, it's important to remove users that aren't active to free up space for more users.

Thank you.
fields.summary: Track Last Logon for Each User, Generate Reports of Inactive or Least Active Users
OpenID 2.0 rel attribute should be specified in discovery HTML

fields.description:
With Crowd 1.6 we are introducing new levels of server-side caching, with configuration options per directory connector. To avoid confusion, we should re-word the label and description for the checkbox which enables/disables the 'has access' cache. The checkbox is on the "General Options" screen of the "Administration" tab.

CURRENT WORDING:
*Label:* Enable Data Caching: 
*Description:* Caching is used to store run-time authentication and authorisation rules which can be expensive to calculate. Recommended settings: Disable during development cycles; enable for production environments.

SUGGESTED NEW WORDING:
*Label:* Enable Authorisation Cache
*Description:* If checked, Crowd will cache a user's authentication and per-application permissions for a specified period. Recommended setting: Enabled, for vastly better performance. Disable only if you need immediate results when removing users or their permissions.
fields.summary: Re-word the label and description for the 'has access' cache checkbox on the Admin Console

fields.description:
To reproduce:
1-) Have a Crucible/FishEye + Crowd + Active Directory environment working (test the environment using a LDAP user with *lowercase characters only* in the username)
2-) Login into FishEye using an *Uppercase username* (see the attached LDAP entry example).
3-) Access Jira. The SSO will log you in automatically.
4-) Logout from FishEye and Jira
5-) Try to login into FishEye using the same user name from step 2, but now, use only lowercase charactes (Example: if {{John}} was used, now, use {{john}}). The login *fails*.
6-) However, if you go to Jira, the user is already logged in. If you go back to FishEye and click the left-top-side logo the user will be logged in.
fields.summary: Crowd SSO doesn't work with Crucible/FishEye when user name has Uppercase characters
Add UI options for new directory types and clean up the descriptions

fields.summary: Possible Bug in Token Random Numbers

fields.description:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Integrating+Crowd+with+Subversion describes using Apache::CrowdAuthz.  This is arguably insufficient for the problem.  

The issue is being able to create new subtrees in subversion and having an administrator be able to set permissions on that subtree without logging into the server.  A perfect example of who I would like to be able to do that is my boss.  He has very little interest in all the details of setting this up, but would feel empowered to be able to do it.

It would be great if a simple UI could be created that managed permissions on the subversion tree. A more complete product might give a web UI to svnadmin even.  

It's an exercise for the reader to figure out if there's a substantial enough market for this, but I would find it helpful.
fields.summary: Crowd plugin to manage mod_authz_svn

fields.description:
When having a large Jira instance integrated with a Crowd LDAP Connector directory, caching thousands of users can take several minutes. If more users try to login while the cache is being populated, the cache data load will start again for each new login tentative. 

This is causing performance and memory problems.
fields.summary: Don't start to populate Crowd's cache again if the data load has already started.

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Status as of 31 October 2013|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3C78B5| titleBGColor=#3C78B5| bgColor=#E7F4FA}

Hi everyone,

Thank you for your votes and comments on this feature request. 

We will be focussing on improving the integration of Crowd within our Atlassian suite of products, as well as simplifying and improving the overall user management and a unified administrative experience. Whilst this particular feature is not a part of a forthcoming release, it remains on our backlog and is potentially something that we would consider implementing in the future.

If our backlog changes and this feature request becomes a priority, this ticket will be updated. If you'd like to better understand how we make roadmap decisions, have a read of : https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DEV/Implementation+of+New+Features+Policy
 
Cheers, Helen Hung
Atlassian Product Management

{panel}

When an account is created by an administrator, have the following options:

* email temp password
* link to the administration console with {{requiresPasswordChange}} set to true, allowing admins to force a password reset.
fields.summary: Email user login details when their account is created in Crowd.

fields.description:
Confluences ConfluenceAuthenticator throws a LoginEvent and LoginFailedEvent whenever someone logs in, or fails logging in.  The crowd ConfluenceAuthenticator class does not throw this event.  This breaks the Confluence userlister macro, which relies on the LoginEvent to know who's online.

It may or may not be the case that this should be fixed in Confluence.
fields.summary: Crowd ConfluenceAuthenticator does not throw LoginEvent

fields.description: LDAP queries in general should not be "contains" or "starts with" or "like". I'm getting whacked by my administrator because the crowd queries are needlessly complex and are all "contains" - i.e. *ray_harrison*. The system should really default to equals (i.e. exact match) and provide the ability to customize how they are done.  Also, there is no need at all to force an object class search. As an example - in Active Directory, all you should have to do is search for sAMAccountName={input user} with nothing else needed. Unfortunately,  I will have to default to the internal LDAP mechanisms in your other products until this can be worked through - great concept though!
fields.summary: LDAP Directory Queries "Contains" Causes Issues

fields.description: Allow native Crowd directories to contain users with blank first or last names.  UI gives something like *The supplied last name is invalid.* when a blank name is used.  For example, I have *Administrator* and *Automation* users.  To work around this problem, I use a *.* in the name.  However, everywhere this appears, it looks very odd.  Prior to Crowd integration, I was able to have nice looking single names in JIRA and Confluence.  If there is some other work around I can use, that would be nice.  I haven't tried updating the database directly.  Sometimes this can cause other problems.
fields.summary: Allow blank first or last names

fields.description: In the screenshot you can see the sub-text to the input field is not lined up with the input text field.
fields.summary: Column alignment is not correct in Safari for the view panel of application / role / group / user objects

fields.description:
Locations:

* principal
* group
* role
* application

This default directory functionality is already present in other locations in the application, such as browsing users / groups / roles.
fields.summary: When an objects in the administration console and there is only one directory, default the directory selection to the only available directory rather than 'select...' option.

fields.description:
Currently the MySQL database option during the install process sets the Hibernate dialect to the MySQLDialect. This is designed for databases prior to MySQL 5.x and by default creates MyISAM tables (which can't perform row-locking).

The way forward would be use [MySQL5InnoDBDialect|http://www.hibernate.org/hib_docs/v3/api/org/hibernate/dialect/MySQL5InnoDBDialect.html].
fields.summary: Update MySQL Hibernate dialect to create transactional InnoDB tables by default

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 8 June 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hello everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Crowd team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-server-bug-fix-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication.

Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Crowd Team
{panel}
 
I'm deploying Crowd and CrowdID into the same container, but they need to have different application.login.url property settings. We would prefer to have the same EAR (which contains Crowd and CrowdID WARs) to be used in dev, qa, and production. However, in each stage, the application.login.url property must be different to match the hostname of the server.

What I would like to do is:
application.login.url = https://${site.name}/openid

and have site.name populated with the site.name system property.
fields.summary: application.login.url doesn't support system property substitution

fields.description:
Our team has been able to successfully implement Openid for our application.
However when I try to login with a different id again without logging on the same system.
It takes me the crowd error page(warning) page : refer to  the screen shot attached...
======================================================================
OpenID Verification Error
 A request has been made to authenticate an OpenID identifier, different from the one you are logged in as. To use a different OpenID, logout and login as a different user.
 ======================================================================
 I am using java 5 + SPRING SECURITY 2 .
======================================================================

I get a Crowd Waring Screen which is not user Friendly.
fields.summary: Develop an ideal Strategy for New User logging in if some user is already logged in from the same system VIA Crowd SSO.

fields.description: A Maven archetype for Crowd is conspicuously missing :)
fields.summary: Maven archetype for a Plugins2 Crowd plugin

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Status as of 27 April 2011|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3C78B5| titleBGColor=#3C78B5| bgColor=#E7F4FA}

Hi folks,
Thanks for your feedback and continued support. We wanted to give you an update on the status of this issue.

Over the near term, the direction we're taking with Crowd is to focus on scalability, reliability and performance. We understand the importance of adding additional connectivity to Crowd, however our efforts are will be used to improve scalability and performance. Because of this, significant improvements to our OpenID support are unlikely to occur in the next 12 months. We will continue to re-evaluate and update this issue when we have more information.
 
Regards,
Eugene Mak
Atlassian Product Management

{panel}

The CrowdID server currently ignores requests for identifier selection (http://specs.openid.net/auth/2.0/identifier_select). This is also known as "directed identity".

CrowdID should populate the identifier field automatically if the remote user is logged in via SSO. If the user is not logged in, then CrowdID should present the user with a log in screen and then process the authentication request.
fields.summary: Support OpenID 2.0 server-side identifier selection

fields.description:
The aim is to provide a REST API for Crowd.

The reasons for this are to make it simpler for administrators to configure and talk to the crowd console either as an "application" or as a "user".

Perhaps they have scripts that create users across multiple systems in their organisation; it is easier to use a REST API than it is to use the SecurityServerClient's SOAP API.
fields.summary: REST API for Crowd

fields.description: I'd like to be able to remotely trigger a directory import on a scheduled basis. I'll take care of the scheduling, but I need Crowd to take care of the importing.
fields.summary: Please create an API method that allows Directory Imports to be done remotely

fields.description:
It would be nice to be able to email (a) user(s) or (a) group(s) of users from within Crowd.
An example use case would be to warn a specific user group that the application they're using will be down for an upgrade.
fields.summary: email users

fields.description: Upgrade to 2.1, specifically to add support for plugins that define a new module type.
fields.summary: Upgrade Crowd to plugins 2.1

fields.description:
When configuring LDAP integration, writing complex filters for the 'Group Object Filter' and 'User Object Filter' fields is difficult at present because the fields only allow about 30 characters. Because the fields have the same design, I'd find it more user friendly if they were all widened to 120 characters or more.

The Configuration tab is displayed at http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Configuring+an+LDAP+Directory+Connector#ConfiguringanLDAPDirectoryConnector-ConfiguringLDAPObjectandAttributeSettings
fields.summary: Lengthen all fields on Configuration tab of LDAP Directory Connector from 30 characters to a longer line

fields.description: There may be circumstances where a user who is logged into crowd from an application, is using another application that is setup to allow crowd SSO between the two apps, however, they are configured to not be allowed to use this application from Crowd, but they can still use the application anonymously.  An example of this is in Studio, where FishEye is configured to allow anonymous access, and a collaborator (someone who doesn't have access to FishEye) is logged into JIRA, and using FishEye anonymously.  In this situation, FishEye will send an isValidToken() request to Crowd for every request the user makes, which in turn will throw an ApplicationAccessDeniedException back to the application.  It would be more efficient to cache fact that the user is not allowed to use the application, for an interval, so as to not hammer the crowd server with isValidToken() requests.  The token itself should also be cached, in case the SSO token changes due to the user logging out of another application, and a user that does have access logging in.
fields.summary: Cache ApplicationAccessDeniedException results

fields.description:
Admittedly this will need the buy in of the JIRA and Confluence PM's.  However, I would like to provide a guide for specific instances.

1.  User or group not found.
2.  Login invalid.
3.  Crowd completely unavailable.

It may also help to provide guidelines for those attempting to integrate other applications with Crowd.
